column1: Before 1 April 2023, will Liz Truss cease to be prime minister of the United Kingdom?
column6: ['Economic Policy', 'Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']
I think we’re done on this one. Sunak ‘kissing of the hands’ and forming government a couple of hours ago. Hate to rely on the Groaniard for exacting details …
Revising to re-state what is now obvious. Unprecedented.

I appreciate your thoughtful comments, @Feyy. Looks like you and I are not going to solve democracy's problems this morning, though--we seem to have arrived at what somebody (I forget who) termed an "embraceable impasse." Thanks.
The 1922 Committee are re-writing century old rules so it can be done by October 28th.
It seems Liz Truss will have managed to make two "in the news in 2023" questions resolve two months before 2023. Impressive.
Is there are an award for Own Goals By A Political Party? Labour might have clinched this if they hadn't dumped Corbyn, but the Tories are the solid favourites now.
Resignation announced
Up 10%. Wonder what is next?
And I just read that she resigned, so updating.
She has made too many mistakes and faces almost insurmountable headwinds. Everything I have read in the news is how she is failing and losing popular support.
done and done
QED
News of her resignation just hit the airwaves a few minutes ago.
Truss resigned apparently: https://news.sky.com/story/liz-truss-to-resign-as-prime-minister-sky-news-understands-12723236
She is done
Increasing as pressure on Truss seems mounting after yesterday's events: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-63325779
Liz Truss has 12 hours to turn things around - Tory MP
Plenty of people who should really know what they're talking about are open about how bad this government is.

Increasing the probability after yesterday's mayhem in parliament to include the damage within the party this has done and because this seems to have been an unforced error (my understanding is that there was no need to set up the fracking vote - which is highly unpopular in UK - as a vote of confidence). Therefore adding another 8%, maintaining that the underlying question who should replace Truss is still not clear while many Tories voting with the unpopular fracking bill might indicate that they do not want the government seen to be resolved.
more chaos in Parliament and another cabinet member sacked.
By all reports coming out today, her government seems to be dissolving.
There are weeks when nothing happens, and then there are weeks when entire years happen.
The front page of BBC news is again awash with Liz Truss's blunders. The sun is setting on her term.

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/18/opinion/liz-truss-uk-hunt.html?campaign_id=2&emc=edit_th_20221019&instance_id=75023&nl=todaysheadlines&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=110400&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1
i feel like i'm slowly inching this one up - how much is signal/noise - i'm still conflicted but...

Increasing the probability after Truss apologised for her mistakes (https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/europa/truss-ruecktritt-grossbritannien-entschuldigung-interview-101.html, sorry for the German article) and her minister interior resigned ("jumped the sinking ship", https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/europa/truss-unterhaus-grossbritannien-103.html). Also reflecting the crowd forecast, I am giving it another 7% as the new minister of the interior is more moderate which allows for a scenario that an actually more moderate cabinet builds up behind Truss who is allowed to govern until the Tory polls have recovered.With the next UK election being scheduled for Jan 2025, I would give a very high 85%+ probability for Truss' term finding a preemptive end. The question here is currently whether the Tories will give her a couple more months or whether they can install someone else.
Home secretary is out (for reasons unclear right now). https://twitter.com/PippaCrerar/status/1582753580746174465
Resignations and/or sacking going on this morning.
Most Tory members say Liz Truss should resign - YouGov, Oct 18, https://yougov.co.uk/topics/politics/articles-reports/2022/10/18/most-tory-members-say-liz-truss-should-resign
Last night on PBS one commentator suggested she might be gone in a matter of weeks.
Front pages of British newspapers, today (Oct 18): https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/oct/18/the-ghost-pm-what-the-papers-say-about-liz-trusss-hold-on-power
I underestimated how much of a train wreck this could become for Truss. Speculation of her impending exit has become so loud and widespread that it may become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Updates from today, Oct 17...
We are forced to update this question by the day now!
A quick update of the forecast based on new from the UK over the weekend.
Cabinet resignations expected imminently

It seems like everyone else reckons there's no way for her to survive as PM. I'll stand by my reasoning for the previous prediction, it was right at the time, but she's just dreadful and there's no amount of U-turning that can save her at this point.

Reporting from the FT and Reuters indicates that there should be a higher probability: https://www.ft.com/content/38b30b44-94c2-4775-8efb-2c95b3e8c447?shareType=nongift and https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/lawmakers-will-try-oust-uk-pm-truss-this-week-daily-mail-2022-10-16/ (thanks to @austhokie for the link!). But the FT's Political Editor also tweets that Hunt is about to announce a big tax rise and spending cut to calm the bond markets (and business?): https://twitter.com/GeorgeWParker/status/1581883782436569089Together does not bring me to fully convince that this will absolutely happen but that I might have been a bit slow in updating my forecast (fist baseline was 30% after all). --> Move up to 55% (incl. the full 30% baseline)
Reporting in Reuters indicating potential for votes of no confidence this week…
On second thought, I think I was not high enough... https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1526375
Up 20% following many fascinating posts. Team Truss is probably on borrowed time. The "there will be a way" is telling.

Liz Truss fights for survival as even allies say she could have only days left - The Guardian, Oct 16, https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/oct/16/liz-truss-fights-for-survival-as-even-allies-say-she-could-have-only-days-left
The odds of Ms. Truss being shown the exit are definitely ticking up.

Honestly don't see a way out for Truss at this point. Rumours of 100 letters of confidence are already in, with 54 being the threshold to hold a vote of no confidence in normal times i.e., after her first 12 months during which she is, in principle, protected against such a vote. The new chancellor hasn't done anything to restore confidence in her, supporting the theory that he's just there as a caretaker to transition to the next PM. If the markets are red tomorrow it will further bury Truss.

Increasing this on the news of MPs publicly calling for Truss to go. I think it’s now possible this comes to a head this week, or next. A chunk of that likelihood depends on market reaction this week whether things will accelerate or not. If gilt rates increase further and end the day tomorrow noticeably higher then then things will happen faster.
https://twitter.com/lewis_goodall/status/1581703318019403777
Up 10% following @ctsats post.

This has gone off the charts very fast; bookies now give odds implying a probability of ~ 55% that she will leave before January 2023. And Daily Star has set a live feed wondering if she will outlast... a lettuce!!!
Poor Truss. She has done so many U-turns it might have been better to just stay still.

Truss had to do another U-turn today, sacking her friend Kwasi, whose tenure in office was the 2nd shortest in history. All of the questions she got from the media challenged her and much of the commentary was about how weak her position is.
One step closer to the firing line, having sacked her friend Kwasi
Following the crowd's momentum and including general awareness of Truss's sinking ship.
Keir Starmer is now calling for a general election. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/oct/14/keir-starmer-uk-election-now-liz-truss-stays-goes-labour
Her tenure looks to be measured in days not weeks or even months. The crisis for the Tory Party is existential.
not sure how much faith to put in it - but a british bookmaker wagering that Truss will be gone before Jan (5/4 odds) - https://www.indy100.com/politics/bookmakers-replace-liz-truss
I am shocked at the speed with which the administration has unravelled, and the potential willingness of many Tory MPs to risk a GE in order to unseat this PM.
Up 30% following the crowd. April is a longish timeline for some Plan B.
The press conference this afternoon was absolutely brutal. She looked on the verge of resigning.
- She is beyond her depth of intellectual capability

There's already a new chancellor in Jeremy Hunt. https://news.sky.com/story/jeremy-hunt-made-chancellor-after-liz-truss-sacks-kwasi-kwarteng-12720267Not the choice I would have expected at first, but Hunt is experienced in Cabinet, was second behind Boris in the 2019 leadership campaign, and generally seen as "safe" (i.e., no ideas that are wacky by tory standards). Hunt backed Sunak in the last leadership campaign and wanted to cut corporation tax (which is now being u-turned on). The idea must be to put him there to reassure and reunite the party (other cabinet members are essentially all Truss supporters from the leadership campaign). The speed of the announcement suggests this move was also planned ahead (how far?) given that Hunt is also out of the country right so he could not have met Truss in person today.This may buy Truss a bit more time, but it's not obvious why Hunt would take the job now since he clearly won't have a good time and has already served in important cabinet positions (health sec, foreign sec) so this wouldn't necessarily be his last chance to make it back into cabinet if Truss was removed. On the other hand, if he expects Truss to be removed, managing to bring a bit of stability could earn him some brownie points in an upcoming leadership campaign or guarantee him a place as chancellor in a possible Sunak government.
Going up as a result of Truss sacking Kwarteng so soon. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/oct/14/liz-truss-press-conference-u-turn-corporation-tax-kwasi-kwarteng

Updating my previous forecast amid the rows about the corporate tax cut and whether it gets slashed. If the more ideological part of Truzz and Kwateng prevails, the voices in the Tory part, including an alleged potential alliance between Rishi Sunak and Penny Mordaunt, that calls for a removal might prevail. If not, the original baseline and arguments against Truzz' removel should still stay.Link:https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/grossbritannien-tories-truss-101.html
“Just in case”, changing forecast to about ~halfway between my current view and the crowd’s take. No particular driver from news sources for this update.

There appears to me even more disarray in communications this week than last week. In the past two days alone there have been briefings (granted not all from the government but all symptomatic of chaos) that:
Black Swan question. The 1922 Commission is unlikely to spurn another Tory PM. That said...
Remote possibility. How would this happen?

I'm having difficulty imagining a future where she survives as PM. She appears to have a very thin understanding of how the country works. She's created a lot of chaos at a time when we badly need calm. And she's running out of allies. But the question has a short deadline and sometimes things take a long time to play out in politics. I need to consider this some more over the coming days and refine my forecast.

I previously thought that the most likely path to Liz Truss being removed was a vote of no confidence in the house of commons (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1514802), which now does seem to be in the minds of some tory MPs after what appears to be a terrible performance by Truss in front of her MPs. This question ends quite soon with respect to the time it might take to convince enough MPs to vote against their government* (or abstain in greater numbers).https://twitter.com/peston/status/1580262987402616837
I think she'll hang on to power, though unpopular by many between now and 1 April 2023.
Yeah this is going from bad to worse. The betting markets think so too.

Truss's commitment today to maintaining public expenditure suggests either a lack of understanding of fiscal realities or an intention to reverse most or all of the 'mini-budget' at the end of October. The first would increase her chances of removal by March; the second would reduce them. Given behaviour to date, the most likely outcome is perhaps an unconvincing combination of the two; a tepid attempt to reverse parts of the budget insufficient to calm markets. I therefore move the forecast up slightly, but will certainly revisit after the statement in late October.

Still think this has a low likelihood to occur. Given all the instability in Europe and the UK economy replacing the PM within 6 months is highly unlikely. Furthermore, in the past ~150 years (a reasonable estimate of "modern time") there has been no PM serving for that short a period (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom_by_length_of_tenure). There is a small chance for health or similar issues causing PM Truss' removal.
God Willing.
It's unlikely, but it's getting more likely.

Uprating the probability of this slightly given the gilt markets' reactions today and growing signs of public discontent among backbench Conservative MPs, though not by a large amount as some of this is offset by the u-turn on on the OBR statement, which more broadly suggests at least some degree of willingness on the part of Truss/Kwarteng to change course in an effort to calm financial markets (admittedly with no guarantee of success).
1. Very rarely do MP's/Party change leaders within a short time frame
Conservatives will only reluctantly change leaders. There is a long time until next general election

I'll take a swing on this, having spent some time following British politics.... so it goes along the lines anyway? So outside view is from a pan-European perspective, or what have you... would not vote Tory nor Labour, I think... ;-)
Up 15% to be above the consensus and following @kevins note below.
Routes for this to resolve as yes:

There are rumours that a party of MPs are looking to replace her now. Which means there are some shenanigans going on in the background. But trying to replace her this quickly would not look good. So there is a chance she will go, but I rate it quite low. Although another major decision that is not likely could change this fast!
She may be able to survive this one mistake and it is to her credit they she knew when to reverse course quickly. If she makes another big mistake she will most likely be gone.

If Liz Truss were to resign, I expect the Tories would feel intense pressure to call a general election. The gap between the Labor party and the Tories has been increasing rapidly in the last few weeks. I don't see the Tories risking a general election before April 1, 2023.
Reasoning
I read:

Setting priors. I will revisit this question nearer to the end date as I expect the optimal strategy would be to replace Liz Truss nearer to the date for a general election. The problem is that the Conservative Party has neither been logical nor consistent for some time.
She is trying to reduce government spending, in a time when people are becoming poorer.
While she screwed up I do not believe that the conservatives are going through another change.
I have to learn to read
I have confidence in her ability.
Leadership contests take at least two months to run and require a leader to quit or face a vote of no confidence prior to being set up by the 1922 committee.
Tory rules prevent a challenge in the time frame.
people don't give up power so easily.
Very initial estimate, until I have time to analyze it better...

Sometimes, the policy is so bad that the person making it requires an intervention. When the entire country knows they’re facing economic disaster and the Conservative’s leadership response was to make it worse, those Tory politicians wishing to save their seats will have no choice but to make the fourth post-Cameron attempt and find someone who can hold back the flood. The longer Liz stays there, the worse it will be.

The reality is both that 1) Liz is probably not especially competent and 2) The economy is going to suck for at least the next 6 months. It may make sense to let her stay around and take the fall later, to have a clean slate with a year and a half left before the next election. If you switch now to someone competent, they may be tainted by the bad economy
Doubtful, given the 1922 Committee's reluctance to oust their former guy. And how quick Ms. Truss was to reverse course in the face of loud public criticism.
Reuters reports today:

According to Matthew Paris’ sensible Times piece, the PM can be dispatched by a vote only if the 1922 Committee wants it. “The ‘22 will want it only if backbenchers overwhelmingly demand it; and if a leader expects to lose such a vote, they’ll resign before it happens. As much a threat as a process, the mechanism may never need to be invoked” (M.Parris )
Its unlikely, but she could expire.
Surely the party will want to convey some stability upon their members
Her party will want to at least give her a year, considering what they have gone thru with the PM she is replacing.
Initial forecast. We live in interesting times.
I don't believe the party will remove her so soon. It will all be about if she calls a snap election.
Long road back but starting to make the right moves finally.
She wasn't that popular with her colleagues in Parliament; they thought she was a light-weight.
My first was way off from the crowd on this one. Overestimated the likelihood of a vote of no confidence. A low-effort prediction on my part and I will suffer the (albeit minor) consequences.

Barely a month in and already a U-turn on a nonsensical tax cuts initiative. She has been handed a challenging situation and as a relatively unknown entity, can't rely on a cult of personality to get by. Tories are slumping at the polls and after the winter hardship that is inevitably coming, somebody's head will have to roll - unfortunately I think it will be Liz

Baseline: If my count is correct, since 2016 three prime minister resigned (not counting those that stepped down after losses in the polls): Cameron '16, May '19, Johnson '22 (funny sidenote and probably coincidence: All resigned in the month of July). Before that I only count one additonal: Machmillan in '63. Therefore, the relevant comparison period seems UK since the Brexit and that makes 3 resignations over the last 6 years for a 50% chance of resignation. 1 April is in a bit less than 7 months, therefore the baseline would be 30%.
Things can move quickly, but April seems too quick:
I’m basically with @alh on this one.

repeating my forecast from the same question that ends in 2024 (https://www.gjopen.com/questions/2543-before-1-january-2024-will-elizabeth-liz-truss-cease-to-be-prime-minister-of-the-united-kingdom), and adjusting further downwards to account for the shorter timeframe.

UK needs stability. b/w the passing of the Queen, the ascension of Prince Charles, the aftermath of Brexit, supporting efforts in Ukraine, and the disgraced exit of Boris Johnson the tolerance for mistakes or missteps in the PMs office is higher.
